definition[0]: when a company takes back new shares that it had offered to its present shareholders, but they do not want to buy, and offers them to other investors
example[0]: Just over 5.2 million new shares are being placed, with 3.1 million subject to clawback.
definition[1]: when an authority gets back money from a person who previously received it from them
example[1]: In the privatisation of Belfast airport, the Audit Office criticized the Treasury for not including a clawback clause on any future resale.
